Observation of unusual ARP traffic patte.Action: Monitor Zeek arp.log for gratuitous ARP replies. Identify gratuitous ARP replies claiming ownership of critical IPs (gateways, DNS servers, etc.). Analyze the frequency and source MAC addresses of these replies. Use descriptive statistics to identify ARP source MACs sending unexpected gratuitous replies for multiple IPs.

Endpoint ARP caches showing multiple IP.Action: Analyze Zeek arp.log entries over time, focusing on ARP replies. Group ARP replies by claimed IP address. Identify instances where the same IP address is claimed by different MAC addresses within a short period, or where a single MAC address claims multiple IPs. Use correlation analysis to link suspicious ARP activity to other network events (e.g., spikes in traffic volume to the poisoned IP).

Identify gratuitous ARP replies claiming ownership of IPs for devices known to host sensitive data or often targeted for collection. Analyze the timing and source of these replies. Use time series analysis to detect sudden occurrences of gratuitous ARPs for these specific targets.

Endpoint ARP caches showing multiple IP.Action: Analyze Zeek arp.log entries over time, focusing on ARP replies. Group ARP replies by claimed IP address. Identify instances where IPs of sensitive data hosts are claimed by unexpected MAC addresses. Calculate the entropy of MAC addresses associated with sensitive IPs; low entropy might indicate a consistent, but potentially malicious, alternate MAC. Correlate suspicious ARP mapping changes with observed network traffic patterns (e.g., redirected traffic).
